reasoning:
First things first: streaming video isn’t in my circle of competence. I’ve spent my life investing in simple businesses—Coca-Cola, See’s Candies, GEICO—where I can peek under the hood and know exactly how the engine runs. Netflix is more akin to a never-ending movie budget mixed with tech algorithms, and that’s a show I don’t understand as well as my own backyard.

When it comes to a moat, I see a brand that’s well known, but one that’s up against deep pockets from Disney, Amazon, Apple and the rest. Inconsistent ROE (only 1 of 10 years above 15%) and volatile earnings growth (–42.9% over 10 periods!) tell me any advantage is fragile at best.

Reed Hastings may be a smart fellow, but there’s no sign of disciplined capital allocation. Heavy debt (debt-to-equity near 4), minimal dividends, and a reinvestment cycle that bleeds cash give me little comfort. I want managers who think like owners, preserve capital and know when to hold or fold—this feels more like a content arms race.

Financially, a ROE of 1.2%, a putty-in-your-hands current ratio, and crazy swings in earnings leave me uneasy. Owner earnings of $28 per share are real, but piling that against a mountain of debt is not my idea of a fortress balance sheet.

Valuation is the final deal-breaker. Your DCF pegs intrinsic value at $314 (even after a 15% haircut), yet the market is bidding nearly twice that. A margin of safety close to –100% means paying almost two dollars for every dollar of value. In my book, that’s buying a wonderful business at a horrible price.

In my corner of the world, I’d much rather own a cigarette-lighter business like See’s Candies—simple, durable pricing power, strong returns, and a valuation that makes sense. So my answer here is a clear no. Netflix is outside what I know, lacks a durable moat, carries too much risk on the balance sheet, and is overpriced by any reasonable standard. I’ll keep my powder dry for moats I understand, at prices that make sense.

fundamental_analysis.details: Weak ROE of 1.2%; High debt to equity ratio of 3.9; Strong operating margins; Current ratio data not available

consistency_analysis.details: Inconsistent earnings growth pattern; Total earnings growth of -42.9% over past 10 periods

moat_analysis.details: Inconsistent ROE: only 0/10 periods >15%; Decent operating margins (avg: 32.4%) suggest some competitive advantage; High performance stability (73.0%) suggests strong competitive moat

book_value_analysis.details: Consistent book value per share growth (Buffett's favorite metric)

management_analysis.details: No significant new stock issuance detected; No or minimal dividends paid

details: Using three-stage DCF: Stage 1 (2.8%, 5y), Stage 2 (1.4%, 5y), Terminal (2.5%)
